thread.title: Terriers power up to beat UConn
thread.title_full: Terriers power up to beat UConn | Boston Herald

author: Herald Staff
title: Terriers power up to beat UConn
text:
Terriers power up to beat UConn Herald Staff Sunday, October 25, 2015 comments Tweet Jakob Forsbacka Karlsson and Brandon Fortunato each potted power-play goals in the third period to snap a 1-1 tie and lift No. 8-ranked Boston University to a 4-2 win against Connecticut yesterday at Agganis Arena in the Hockey East opener for both teams.
BU (2-1-0, 1-0-0 HE) scored the lone goal of the opening period when freshman Ryan Cloonan backhanded a rebound over UConn netminder Rob Nichols. The Huskies responded with the only tally of the middle stanza to create a 1-1 deadlock entering the third.
Forsbacka Karlsson’s first career goal gave the Terriers the lead at the 5:50 mark of the third. Fortunato doubled the lead exactly three minutes later, during a five-minute major power play for the Terriers.
With Nichols off for the extra skater, UConn’s Max Letunov scored his second goal of the night to make it 3-2 with 23.6 seconds to play. But Brandon Hickey sealed the deal for BU with an empty netter.
Sean Maguire made 16 saves in the BU net to earn his first win of the season.
UMass-Lowell 1, Merrimack 1 — Brian Christie gave the No. 19 Warriors (2-0-2, 0-0-2) the lead at 13:45 of the second period, but Michael Kapla equalized just 44 seconds later as the host No. 7 RiverHawks (3-0-2, 0-0-2) earned the Hockey East tie at Tsongas Center.
Kevin Boyle made 22 saves for UML, while Merrimack counterpart Collin Delia had 17 stops.
Providence 6, Ohio State 4 — The No. 3 Friars (4-0-1) built a 3-0 lead after one period, and added three power-play goals in the final 40 minutes to hold off the visiting Buckeyes (0-6-0) to complete a weekend sweep of their nonleague foe at Schneider Arena.
Trevor Mingola led Providence’s balanced attack (six scorers) by notching three assists. Defenseman John Gilmour was the only other multi-point Friar with a goal and an assist, and Nick Ellis made 30 saves.
North Dakota 5, Vermont 2 — Jarrid Privitera scored twice, both assisted by Liam Coughlin, but the Catamounts (1-4-0) were beaten by Brock Boeser (goal, assist) and No. 1 North Dakota (4-0-2) in Burlington, Vt.
New Hampshire 5, Union 2 — In Schnectady, N.Y., Tyler Kelleher had a goal and two assists and Adam Clark made 34 saves to power the Wildcats (2-2-1) to the nonleague victory over the No. 18 Dutchmen (2-1-3).
Holy Cross 4, Canisius 1 — Michael Laffin scored 2:29 into play, and then set up two more first period tallies to power the Crusaders (1-4-0, 1-1-0) to the Atlantic Hockey win over the Golden Griffins (1-3-0, 1-1-0) in Buffalo, N.Y. Tommy Nixon made 24 saves for HC.
Women
Northeastern 7, Boston University 1 — Leading scorer Kendall Coyne set up two goals as the No. 10 Huskies (5-1-1, 1-0-0) sported seven goalscorers to blow out the Terriers (3-4-0, 2-1-0) in their Hockey East opener at Matthews Arena.
Hayley Masters had a goal and an assist to give NU a 2-0 lead. Four other Huskies — Paige Savage, Heather Mottau, Hayley Scamurra and Maddie Hartman — also had goal-assist games, and Brittany Bugalski made 30 saves for the win.
Boston College 8, Cornell 0 — Alex Carpenter notched the hat trick, while Makenna Newkirk (two goals) and Haley Skarupa (goal) also had three-point games as the No. 2 Eagles (8-0-0) dominated the No. 9 Big Red (0-2-0) in Ithaca, N.Y. Katie Burt made 23 saves to earn the shutout.
